{{EngvarB|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} [[File:CIA aerial view Osama bin Laden compound Abbottabad.jpg|thumb|250px|The classified papers analysed the unilateral military actions of US military forces in Pakistan that occurred in 2011.]] The '''Abbottabad Commission Report''' is a judicial inquiry paper authored and submitted by the [[Abbottabad Commission]], led by [[List of Justices of the Supreme Court of Pakistan|Justice]] [[Javaid Iqbal]], to the [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] of Pakistan on 4 January 2013.<ref name="The News International, 2013">{{cite news|last=Staff correspondents|title=Abbottabad Commission report submitted to PM|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-13-19995-Abbottabad-Commission-report-submitted-to-PM|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=The News International, 2013|date=4 January 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502002555/http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-13-19995-Abbottabad-Commission-report-submitted-to-PM|archivedate=2 May 2014}}</ref> The report investigates the circumstances surrounding the [[death of Osama bin Laden]] in Abbottabad. Upon submission, the report was immediately classified by the Prime Minister and its findings were not made public.<ref name="Express Tribune, 06/13">{{cite news|last=Khan|first=Sumera|title=Two years on: Abbottabad report remains out of sight|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/543834/two-years-on-abbottabad-report-remains-out-of-sight/|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=Express Tribune, 06/13|date=3 May 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502031901/http://tribune.com.pk/story/543834/two-years-on-abbottabad-report-remains-out-of-sight/|archivedate=2 May 2014}}</ref>
Indicated by the media, the report compiled the 700-pages, which lists some 200 recommendations after interviewing over 300 witnesses and scrutinising more than 3,000 documents pertaining to the [[Death of Osama bin Laden|raid]] by US [[Joint Special Operations Command|special operations forces]] to kill [[al-Qaeda]] leader [[Osama bin Laden]] on 2 May 2011.<ref name="Express Tribune, 01/13">{{cite web|last=Staff|title=Abbottabad Commission: Report on bin Laden out, but not public|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/488865/abbottabad-commission-report-on-bin-laden-out-but-not-public/|work=4 January 2013|publisher=Express Tribune, 01/13|accessdate=27 June 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102200156/http://tribune.com.pk/story/488865/abbottabad-commission-report-on-bin-laden-out-but-not-public/|archivedate=2 January 2014}}</ref> In response to American unilateral actions, the government formed the commission which was to find out exactly what happened and who was responsible for failing to catch the high-profile target, who had taken refuge in Abbottabad. In 2013, parts of the reports published by the [[News channels in Pakistan|news channels]] in the country and most of the findings of the said report were leaked to the press and were strongly criticised by defence experts.<ref name="Express Tribune, 06/13"/> The government then classified all of its publications despite American reservations and concerns,<ref name="Samma TV report">{{cite news|last=Newsdesk|title=Pak-US people need to see Abbottabad commission report|url=http://www.samaa.tv/newsdetail.aspx?ID=55658|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=Samma TV report|date=23 October 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102200029/http://www.samaa.tv/newsdetail.aspx?ID=55658|archivedate=2 January 2014}}</ref> but the report was released by [[Al Jazeera]] on 8 July 2013.<ref name="AlJaz20130708" />
==Background== In 2011, the United States took [[Death of Osama bin Laden|unilateral]] actions to target and kill [[al-Qaeda]] leader [[Osama Bin Laden]], who was reportedly in hiding in [[Abottabad]], in the [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province]] of [[Pakistan]].<ref name="Daily Times, Pakistan"/> After much criticism, Prime Minister [[Yousaf Raza Gillani]] formed the commission under Senior Justice [[Javed Iqbal (Judge)|Javed Iqbal]].<ref name="Daily Times, Pakistan"/> Soon after conducting session interviews, Senior Justice [[Javed Iqbal (Judge)|Iqbal]] announced that Abbottabad Commission report will be made public in a few weeks.<ref name="AAJ Television">{{cite news|last=Ejaz|first=Muhammad|title=Abbottabad Commission report to become public in a few weeks: Justice Javed|url=http://www.aaj.tv/2011/12/commission-report-to-become-public-in-a-few-weeks-justice-javed/|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=AAJ Television|date=21 December 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502004409/http://www.aaj.tv/2011/12/commission-report-to-become-public-in-a-few-weeks-justice-javed/|archivedate=2 May 2014}}</ref> Despite Iqbal's claims, the commission did not release the report and its preparation period further prolonged to next years.<ref name="News Tribe">{{cite news|last=Hussain|first=Mirza|title=Abbottabad Commission to present report next month.|url=http://www.thenewstribe.com/2012/05/24/abbottbad-commission-to-present-report-next-month/|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=News Tribe|date=24 May 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140501235528/http://www.thenewstribe.com/2012/05/24/abbottbad-commission-to-present-report-next-month/|archivedate=1 May 2014}}</ref>
In 2012, the Pakistani [[Ministry of Justice (Pakistan)|Ministry of Justice]] (MoJ) issued a notification to the commission on asking to complete its investigation and submit the report on 12 October 2012.<ref name="Daily Times, Pakistan">{{cite news|last=Staff|title=Abbottabad Commission given 30 days to submit report|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2012\09\12\story_12-9-2012_pg7_15|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=Daily Times, Pakistan|date=12 September 2012}}</ref>
Parts of the report duly recommended a trial against the medical doctor-turned spy, Dr. [[Shakil Afridi]].<ref name="News Tribe" /> Asked by a journalist for delaying of the report, Senior Justice Iqbal maintained that the presence of CIA in Pakistan is also being investigated, adding that it would be mentioned in the report.<ref name="AAJ Television" /> To another question by a journalist as to [[Osama bin Laden death conspiracy theories|whether the person]] killed in the compound in Abbottabad was [[Osama bin Laden]], Justice Javed Iqbal quoted: If we tell you that what's left.... You'll find out soon."<ref name="AAJ Television" />
==Contents==
Revealed by the British ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', the papers ultimately cleared the [[Government of Pakistan|Government]], [[Pakistan Armed Forces|armed forces]], the [[The Establishment|establishment]], and intelligence services of involvement in protection of the al-Qaeda chief.<ref name="The Nation">{{cite news|last=Staff|title=Abbottabad Commission clears Pak govt, military of protecting Osama|url=http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/national/22-Oct-2012/abbottabad-commission-clears-pak-govt-military-of-protecting-osama|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=The Nation|date=22 October 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016143849/http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/national/22-Oct-2012/abbottabad-commission-clears-pak-govt-military-of-protecting-osama|archivedate=16 October 2013}}</ref> American literary political critics have accused Pakistan officials of knowing more about Osama's presence than they were letting on.<ref name="The Nation"/> United States had been long demanding Pakistan to declassify the papers of the reports, maintaining that it is important for the Pakistani and American public to see the report of Abbottabad Commission.<ref name="Samma TV report" /> All request had been dismissed by the [[Government of Pakistan|Government]] of Pakistan.<ref name="The Nation"/>
===Classified status=== Before the full submission of the papers in 2013, only a few parts of the papers were obtained by the [[Dunya News|''World News]] channel of Pakistan and televised it all over the nation in 2012.<ref name="Dunya News (World News)">{{cite news|last=News Desk|title=Dunya News gets copy of Abbottabad Commission report|url=http://dunyanews.tv/index.php/en/Pakistan/147839-Dunya-News-gets-copy-of-Abbottabad-Commission-repo|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=Dunya News (World News)|date=9 December 2012}}</ref> Following the broadcast, the [[United States Department of State|US State Department]] declined to comment on the report.<ref name="Top News USA">{{cite news|last=Williamson|first=Jamie|title=U.S. declines to comment on Osama Abbottabad Commission report|url=http://www.topnews.in/usa/us-declines-comment-osama-abbottabad-commission-report-221586|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=Top News USA|date=23 October 2012}}</ref>
In an official press briefing to media, the US State Department maintained that "U.S. shares with Pakistan a "profound" interest in learning about what kind of support network al-Qaeda chief Osama bin Laden might have had during his hiding but would only comment on the Abbottabad Commission's findings on the issue when it gets the actual report."<ref name="Pakistan Times">{{cite news|last=Staff Correspondents|title=US has profound interest in Abbottabad Commission report|url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2012/10/22/news/national/us-has-profound-interest-in-abbottabad-commission-report/|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=Pakistan Times|date=22 October 2012}}</ref> Sensing the impact on the military, the defence authors had had earlier hinted to media that the papers would be marked as [[Classified information|classified]] expect little of substance to be revealed.<ref name="Pakistan Times (Web cache)"/> Excerpts leaked to the press from the yet-to-be-made-public report differed with the American account of the incident.<ref name="Pakistan Times (Web cache)">{{cite news|last=Staff|title=Abbottabad Commission: Report on bin Laden out, but not public|url=http://pakistannewstoday.4com.co/abbottabad-commission-report-on-bin-laden-out-but-not-public/|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=Pakistan Times (Web cache)|date=4 January 2013}}</ref>
In January 2013, the final report was submitted to Prime Minister [[Raja Pervez Ashraf|Pervez Ashraf]] to review the papers. After briefly reviewing the papers, Prime Minister Ashraf [[Classified information|classified]] the publications of the report before leaving the office.<ref name="Express Tribune, 06/13"/><ref name="Pakistan Times 2013">{{cite news|last=Hussain|first=Tayyab|title=Pakistanis still in the dark over Bin Laden raid|url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2013/05/02/news/national/pakistanis-still-in-the-dark-over-bin-laden-raid/|accessdate=28 June 2013|newspaper=Pakistan Times 2013|date=2 May 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511135934/http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2013/05/02/news/national/pakistanis-still-in-the-dark-over-bin-laden-raid/|archivedate=11 May 2013}}</ref>
===Al Jazeera report leak=== The report of the Abbottabad Commission,<ref>{{cite web|title=Document: Pakistan's Bin Laden Dossier |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/spotlight/binladenfiles/2013/07/201378143927822246.html |work=[[Abbottabad Commission]] |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=8 July 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6I7fpcDHf?url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/spotlight/binladenfiles/2013/07/201378143927822246.html |archivedate=15 July 2013 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> formed in June 2011 to probe the circumstances around the killing of Osama bin Laden by American forces in a unilateral raid on the Pakistani city of Abbottabad, was leaked by the Al Jazeera Investigative Unit on 8 July 2013, after being suppressed by the Pakistani government.<ref name="AlJaz20130708">{{cite web|last=HAshim|first=Asad|title=Leaked report shows Bin Laden's 'hidden life'|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2013/07/20137813412615531.html|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=8 July 2013|date=8 July 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140430164359/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2013/07/20137813412615531.html|archivedate=30 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Burke|first=Jason|title=Pakistan's Abbottabad report is serious, savage self-analysis|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/08/pakistan-abbottabad-report-savage-self-analysis?INTCMP=SRCH|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=8 July 2013}}</ref><ref name="TGBoone20130708">{{cite news|last=Boone|first=Jon|title=Osama bin Laden: Pakistan criticised over failure to capture al-Qaida chief|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/08/osama-bin-laden-pakistan-criticised?INTCMP=SRCH|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=8 July 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725210846/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2013/jul/08/osama-bin-laden-pakistan-criticised?INTCMP=SRCH|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref><ref name="BBCNews20130708">{{cite web|title=Leaked report reveals Pakistan failures on Bin Laden|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-23235847|publisher=BBC News Asia|accessdate=9 July 2013|date=8 July 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101013935/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-23235847|archivedate=1 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="WP20130708" /><ref name="NYT20130708" /> The report drew on testimony from more than 200 witnesses, including members of Bin Laden's family, Pakistan's then spy chief Ahmad Shuja Pasha, senior ministers in the government and officials at every level of the military, bureaucracy and security services.<ref name="AlJaz20130708" /> The four-member Abbottabad Commission interviewed 201 people, including the country's intelligence leaders, in an effort to piece together the events around the American raid on 2 May 2011, that killed Bin Laden, the leader of Al Qaeda, and embarrassed the Pakistani government. The commission was led by Justice Javed Iqbal of the Pakistani Supreme Court, a retired police officer, a diplomat and an army general. It first met in July 2011, two months after the American raid, and has held 52 hearings and conducted seven field visits.<ref name="NYT20130708" />
Osama bin Laden was able to hide in Pakistan for nine years due to the "collective failure" of state military and intelligence authorities and "routine" incompetence at every level of civil governance structure allowed the once world's most wanted man to move to six different locations within the country.<ref name="AlJaz20130708" /> The Commission's 336-page report is scathing, holding both the government and the military responsible for "gross incompetence" leading to "collective failures" that allowed both Bin Laden to escape detection, and the United States to perpetrate "an act of war".<ref name="AlJaz20130708" /> It found that Pakistan's intelligence establishment had "closed the book" on bin Laden by 2005, and was no longer actively pursuing intelligence that could lead to his capture. The Abbottabad Commission report blasted the Pakistani government and military for a "national disaster" over its handling of bin Laden and calls on the leadership to apologise to the people of Pakistan for their "dereliction of duty."<ref name="USAToday20130708">{{cite news|last=Stanglin|first=Doug|title=Leaked Pakistan report details bin Laden's secret life|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/07/08/pakistan-commission-osama-bin-laden-al-jazeera-leaked-report/2498565/|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=8 July 2013}}</ref>
The document repeatedly returned to what it describes as "government implosion syndrome" to explain the failure of any institution to investigate Bin Laden's unusual hideout.<ref name="TGBoone20130708" /> "It is a glaring testimony to the collective incompetence and negligence, at the very least, of the security and intelligence community in the Abbottabad area," said the report.<ref name="TGBoone20130708" /> "How the entire neighbourhood, local officials, police and security and intelligence officials all missed the size, the strange shape, the barbed wire, the lack of cars and visitors … over a period of nearly six years beggars belief," it said.<ref name="TGBoone20130708" /><ref name="BBCNews20130708" /> The report said that Bin Laden must have required a support network "that could not possibly have been confined to the two Pashtun brothers who worked as his couriers, security guards and general factotums".<ref name="TGBoone20130708" /> The report said: "Over a period of time an effective intelligence agency should have been able to contact, infiltrate or co-opt them and to develop a whole caseload of information. Apparently, this was not the case."<ref name="TGBoone20130708" /> The commission didn't rule out the possibility of involvement by rogue Pakistani intelligence officers, who have been accused of deliberately shielding Bin Laden by some commentators.<ref name="TGBoone20130708" /><ref name="BBCNews20130708" /> "Given the length of stay and the changes of residence of [Bin Laden] and his family in Pakistan … the possibility of some such direct or indirect and "plausibly deniable" support cannot be ruled out, at least, at some level outside formal structures of the intelligence establishment."<ref name="TGBoone20130708" /> "Connivance, collaboration and cooperation at some levels cannot be entirely discounted," it said.<ref name="NYT20130708">{{cite news|last=Walsh|first=Declan|title=Leaked Report Cites Pakistan's Failings Before U.S. Killed Bin Lade|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/09/world/asia/leaked-report-cites-pakistans-failings-before-us-killed-bin-laden.html|accessdate=9 July 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=8 July 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725173440/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/09/world/asia/leaked-report-cites-pakistans-failings-before-us-killed-bin-laden.html|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref>
The commission made several findings. Among these include:<ref name="USAToday20130708" /> * Osama bin Laden entered Pakistan in mid-2002 after narrowly escaping capture in the [[battle of Tora Bora]] in Afghanistan. Over nine years, he moved to various places inside the country, including [[South Waziristan]] and northern [[Swat Valley]]. * In Swat, the al-Qaeda leader reportedly met with [[Khalid Sheikh Mohammad]], the alleged mastermind of the [[9/11 attacks]], in early 2003. About a month later, KSM was captured in Rawalpindi in a joint US-Pakistani operation, and bin Laden fled the area. * Osama bin Laden, along with two of his wives and several children and grandchildren, moved into the custom-built compound in Abbottabad, a military garrison town, in 2005 and lived there until the US raid. * Osama bin Laden was very concerned about surveillance. The report says bin Laden wore a [[cowboy hat]] outside to avoid detection from above and considered buying and cutting down a row of [[poplar tree]]s on the perimeter of the Abbottabad compound because he thought it might provide cover for observers. * The presence of a CIA support network to help track down bin Laden without the Pakistani establishment's knowledge was "a case of nothing less than a collective and sustained dereliction of duty by the political, military and intelligence leadership of the country."
With respect to the [[Death of Osama bin Laden|death of bin Laden]] at the hands of US Navy SEALs, the report concluded:
{{quote|The whole episode of the U.S. assassination mission of May 2, 2011 and the Pakistan government's response before, during and after appears in large part to be a story of complacency, ignorance, negligence, incompetence, irresponsibility and possibly worse at various levels inside and outside the government.<ref name="USAToday20130708" />}}
The Pakistani military's inability to prevent an American incursion into its airspace was described as the country's greatest "humiliation" since 1971, when Indian forces routed Pakistan in a war that led to the creation of the present-day state of [[Bangladesh]], according to the report. Despite American assurances that US forces would enter Pakistan if they thought they could capture Osama bin Laden, Pakistani air defences were set to a "peace time mode" when American helicopters crossed into Pakistani airspace, the report stated.<ref name="WP20130708" /> The report didn't name the persons responsible for the failures in the hunt for bin Laden as well as the American intrusion into Pakistan and said that it may be politically unrealistic to suggest punishments for them, but "as honourable men, they ought to do the honourable thing, including submitting a formal apology to the nation for their [[dereliction of duty]]."<ref name="WP20130708">{{cite news|last=Craig|first=Tim|title=Pakistan faults self in bin Laden hunt|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/pakistan-faults-self-in-bin-laden-hunt/2013/07/08/999706d4-e813-11e2-818e-aa29e855f3ab_story.html|accessdate=9 July 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=8 July 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
{{redirect|Grosart|the politician|Allister Grosart}}
'''Alexander Balloch Grosart''' (18 June 1827{{snd}}16 March 1899) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] clergyman and literary [[editing|editor]]. He is chiefly remembered for reprinting much rare [[Elizabethan era|Elizabethan]] literature, a work which he undertook because of his interest in [[Puritan]] [[theology]].
==Life==
The son of a building contractor, he was born at [[Stirling]] and educated at the [[University of Edinburgh]]. In 1856 he became a minister of the [[United Presbyterian Church of Scotland]] at [[Kinross]], serving the congregation known as First United Presbyterian Church. In 1865 he went to [[Liverpool]], and three years later to [[Blackburn]].<ref name="EB 1911">{{EB1911|inline=y|wstitle=Grosart, Alexander Balloch|volume=12|page=615}}</ref>
He resigned from the ministry in 1892, and died at [[Dublin]].
==Editorial work==
Among the first writers whose works he edited were the Puritan writers, [[Richard Sibbes]], [[Thomas Brooks (writer)|Thomas Brooks]] and [[Herbert Palmer (Puritan)|Herbert Palmer]]. Editions of [[Michael Bruce (poet)|Michael Bruce]]'s ''Poems'' (1865) and [[Richard Gilpin]]'s ''Demonologia sacra'' (1867) followed. In 1868 he brought out a bibliography of the writings of [[Richard Baxter]], and from that year until 1876 he was occupied in reproducing for private subscribers the “Fuller Worthies Library,” a series of thirty-nine volumes which included the works of [[Thomas Fuller]], Sir [[John Davies (poet)|John Davies]], [[Fulke Greville, 1st Baron Brooke|Fulke Greville]], [[Edward de Vere]], [[Henry Vaughan]], [[Andrew Marvell]], [[George Herbert]], [[Richard Crashaw]], [[John Donne]] and Sir [[Philip Sidney]]. The last four volumes of the series were devoted to the works of many little known and otherwise inaccessible authors.<ref name="EB 1911"/> He also wrote a biography of the Scottish poet, [[Robert Fergusson]] (Edinburgh: [[Oliphant, Anderson and Ferrier]], 1898) in the [[List of books for the "Famous Scots Series"|“Famous Scots Series”]].
His ''Occasional Issues of Unique and Very Rare Books'' (1875–1881) included among other things the ''Annalia Dubrensia'' of [[Robert Dover (Cotswold Games)|Robert Dover]]. In 1876 still another series, known as the “Chertsey Worthies Library,” was begun. It included editions of the works of [[Nicholas Breton]], [[Francis Quarles]], [[Joseph Beaumont|Dr Joseph Beaumont]], [[Abraham Cowley]], [[Henry More]] and [[John Davies of Hereford]].<ref name="EB 1911"/>
The two last-named series were being produced simultaneously until 1881, and no sooner had they been completed than Grosart began the “Huth Library,” so called from the bibliophile [[Henry Huth (bibliophile)|Henry Huth]], who possessed the originals of many of the reprints. It included the works of [[Robert Greene (16th century)|Robert Greene]], [[Thomas Nashe]], [[Gabriel Harvey]], and the prose tracts of [[Thomas Dekker (poet)|Thomas Dekker]]. He also edited the complete works of [[Edmund Spenser]] and [[Samuel Daniel]]. From the Townley Hall collection he reprinted several manuscripts and edited [[John Eliot (statesman)|Sir John Eliot]]'s works, [[Richard Boyle, 1st Earl of Cork|Sir Richard Boyle]]'s ''Lismore Papers'', and various publications for the [[Chetham Society]], the [[Camden Society]] and the [[Roxburghe Club]].<ref name="EB 1911"/>
=== Religious works === * ''[https://archive.org/details/jesusmightytosa00grosgoog Jesus 'mighty to save': Isaiah lxiii.1 or, Christ for all the world, and all the world for Christ]'' (1863) * ''[https://archive.org/details/joiningchurchor02grosgoog Joining the Church, Or, Materials for Conversations Between a Minister and Intending Communicant]'' (1865) * ''[https://archive.org/details/lambsallsafeors00grosgoog The Lambs All Safe: Or, the Salvation of Children]'' (1865)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{wikisource author}} *{{Gutenberg author|id=Alexander_B._Grosart|name=Alexander Balloch Grosart}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Alexander Balloch Grosart}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Grosart, Alexander Balloch}} [[Category:1827 births]] [[Category:1899 deaths]] [[Category:People from Stirling]] [[Category:19th-century Presbyterian ministers]] [[Category:Scottish Christians]] [[Category:Scottish clergy]] [[Category:Scottish publishers (people)]] [[Category:British literary editors]] [[Category:Contributors to the Oxford English Dictionary]] [[Category:Contributors to the Dictionary of National Biography]]

revision.text: {{more citations needed|date=January 2013}} [[File:Archeological playing card.jpg|thumb|Sample of the cards.]] The '''archaeology awareness playing cards''' are a set of [[playing cards]] developed by the [[United States Department of Defense]] designed to educate members of the [[United States military]] serving in [[Iraq War|Iraq]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]] about the importance of respecting ancient monuments, to try to preserve the Iraqi and Afghan national [[cultural heritage]]. The goal of the publication of the cards was two-fold according to Fort Drum archaeologist Laurie Rush - to prevent unnecessary damage to ancient sites and to stem the illegal trade of artifacts in Iraq. The military has long recognized that educational playing cards are a good way to capitalize on the time soldiers spend waiting for orders. They were devised following the success of the [[most-wanted Iraqi playing cards]] (officially called "personality identification playing cards") that were used in the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]] to help members of the U.S. military identify wanted personnel from the Baathist regime. Approximately 40,000 sets of the cards were issued to U.S. forces. In the archaeology deck, each suit has a theme: diamonds for artifacts, spades for digs, hearts for "winning hearts and minds," and clubs for heritage preservation.http://www.archaeology.org/0707/trenches/solitaire.html ==About the cards== ===Spades=== * Ace ♠: "Ancient walls of mud brick are easily damaged." * King ♠: "Many DoD sites in the US have protected archaeological sites. Learn more about your home installation." [[Fort Drum|Lewisburg Furnace]], [[Fort Drum, New York]], [[United States|United States of America]]. * Queen ♠: "Use a monitor when digging in archaeologically sensitive areas." * Jack ♠: "Stop digging if you find artifacts or features." * Ten ♠: "Heavy excavation equipment can do great harm to archaeological sites. Be aware and prepare to stop." * Nine ♠: "Helicopter rotor wash can damage archaeological sites. Avoid where possible." * Eight ♠: "Every DoD installation has a cultural resources manager. Call yours with questions about archaeology, history, or culture." * Seven ♠: "Taking pictures is good. Removing artifacts for souvenirs is not!" * Six ♠: "Use your camera to document archaeological and historic sites." * Five ♠: "A looted archaeological site means that details of our common past are lost forever." * Four ♠: "If possible, fill sandbags with clean earth, free of man-made objects." * Three ♠: "Leave artifacts like broken pottery or inscribed bricks in place." * Two ♠: "In the dry climate of the Middle East, a wall of mud brick could be thousands of years old." [[Qalai Bost]], [[Afghanistan]]. ===Clubs=== * Ace ♣: "The DoD needs your help in protecting heritage resources." * King ♣: "Remember [[Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict|this international symbol]] for a PROTECTED CULTURAL SITE." * Queen ♣: "Remember! The buying and selling of antiquities is ''not'' condoned by the U.S. Armed Forces." * Jack ♣: "Ancient cultural artifacts and objects of art are also heritage resources that must be protected." * Ten ♣: "A mound or small hill in an otherwise flat landscape could be a sign of ancient human occupation." [[Rimah|Tell Rimah]], [[Iraq]]. * Nine ♣: "Future generations will be thankful for the monuments and sites spared today." [[Mosques and shrines of Mosul|Bent Minaret]], [[Mosques and shrines of Mosul|Mosul's Great Mosque]], [[Iraq]]. * Eight ♣: "Stop digging immediately you find buried walls, broken pottery, or other artifacts. Report what you find!" Ancient walls near [[Great Ziggurat of Ur]], [[Iraq]]. * Seven ♣: "This site has survived for seventeen centuries. Will it survive you?". [[Ctesiphon|Ctesiphon Arch]], [[Iraq]]. * Six ♣: "Respect ruins wherever possible. They protect you and your cultural history." [[Great Mosque of Samarra|Samarra Minaret]] (Malwiya), [[Iraq]]. * Five ♣: "Drive around - not over - archaeological sites". * Four ♣: "Look before you dig!" * Three ♣: "No [[graffiti]]! Defacing walls or ruins with [[Spray painting|spray paint]] or other materials is disrespectful and counterproductive to the mission" * Two ♣: "Ancient Iraqi heritage is part of your heritage. Old stories say that [[Jonah]] of the bible {{sic}} was buried in this hill." ([[Mosques and shrines of Mosul|Naba Yunis Mosque]] in [[Mosul]], [[Iraq]]) ===Hearts=== * Ace ♥: "The main goal of archaeology is to understand the past - ''your'' past." * King ♥: "If it's a defensible position today, it may have been for thousands of years. Watch for archaeological remains." * Queen ♥: "Archaeological sites matter to the local community. Showing respect wins hearts and minds." * Jack ♥: "Local elders may be a good source of information about cultural heritage and archaeology." * Ten ♥: "Religious monuments, such as the [[Buddhas of Bamyan|Bamian Buddhas]] in Afghanistan, are often targets for intentional destruction during times of conflict." [[Buddhas of Bamyan]], [[Bamiyan Province]], [[Afghanistan]]. * Nine ♥: "The [[Bible|Bible's]] [[Tower of Babel]] referred to an Iraqi [[Ziggurat]]." [[Great Ziggurat of Ur]], [[Iraq]]. * Eight ♥: "Iraq's civilisation originated in the [[Fertile Crescent]] between the [[Tigris]] and [[Euphrates]] Rivers. Humans first created agricultural settlements here over 8,000 years ago." * Seven ♥: "Iraq has been described as the "[[Cradle of Civilisation]]." Illustration of the Northwest Palace Throne Room at [[Nimrud]], [[Iraq]]. * Six ♥: The world's oldest complete [[Hammurabi's Code|legal code]] was found in Iraq on a stone carved with an image of [[Hammurabi]], [[King of Babylon]], ca. 1760 B.C." * Five ♥: "Protecting archaeological sites helps preserve them for future generations." * Four ♥: "Protecting art and archaeology is the responsibility of all ranks within a unit." * Three ♥: "To understand the meaning of an artifact, it must be found and studied in its original setting." [[Hoard of Sumerian statues]], [[Asmar|Tell Asmar]], [[Iraq]]. * Two ♥: "Ninety-nine percent of mankind's history can only be understood through archaeology". Ancient ruins at [[Samarra]], [[Iraq]]. ===Diamonds=== * Ace ♦: "Buying looted artifacts is forbidden. These objects will be confiscated if discovered." * King ♦: "Buddhist statuary from [[Hadda, Afghanistan|Hadda]] in [[Afghanistan]] has been heavily looted for [[Illicit antiquities|sale on the illegal market]]." * Queen ♦: "Monumental art, such as the [[Buddhas of Bamyan|Bamian Buddhas]] in Afghanistan, should be preserved in place for all humankind." [[Buddhas of Bamyan]], [[Bamiyan Province]], [[Afghanistan]]. * Jack ♦: "How would you feel if someone stole her torch?" [[Statue of Liberty]], [[New York City]], [[United States of America]]. * Ten ♦: "[[Mesopotamia]] is considered the birthplace of [[writing]]. [[Clay tablet]]s such as this one are primary evidence." Ancient [[Cuneiform script|cuneiform]] tablet from [[Nippur]], [[Iraq]]. * Nine ♦: "The Joint Interagency Task Force recovered more than 5,000 artifacts, including this one stolen from the [[Iraq Museum]]." [[Mask of Warka]]. * Eight ♦: "The Joint Interagency Task Force recovered 62,000 artifacts removed from the [[National Museum of Iraq|Iraq Museum]] in the years, months, and weeks before the war." * Seven ♦: "Museums are also victims of warfare and need protection where possible." [[Kabul Museum]], [[Afghanistan]]. * Six ♦: "Thousands of artifacts are disappearing from Iraq and Afghanistan. Report suspicious behaviour." * Five ♦: "Looters leave destructive holes and tunnels throughout archaeological sites. Report all observed war damage and looting." * Four ♦: "Report to your [[Officer in charge (police)|OIC]] any observed looting activity or attempts to sell or purchase ancient artifacts." * Three ♦: "Purchasing ancient "souvenirs" helps fund [[Insurgency|insurgent]]s. Do not buy them!" * Two ♦: "[[Cylinder seals]] look like carved pieces of chalk. As with other artifacts, do not buy them!" cylinder seals ===Other=== The set also contained other cards such as the jokers that provided additional information about heritage preservation. ==Award== On November 7, 2007, the DoD program, entitled "In-Theater Heritage Training for Deploying Personnel", was awarded the "Chairman's Award" from the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation, an independent federal agency that promotes the preservation, enhancement, and productive use of the United States of America's historic resources, and advises the President and Congress on national historic preservation policy.[http://www.defenselink.mil/releases/release.aspx?releaseid=11462 DoD Receives Chairman's Award From Advisory Council on Historic Preservation], Press release No. 1285-07, Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense (Public Affairs), U.S. Department of Defense. November 06, 2007 ==See also== *[[Most-wanted Iraqi playing cards]] *[[Archaeology]] *[[Archaeology Magazine]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.archaeology.org/0707/trenches/solitaire.html Archaeology Magazine] *[http://www.art-for-a-change.com/blog/2007/06/archaeology-awareness-playing-cards.html Mark Vallen] *[http://www.defenselink.mil/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=46517 ''Program Seeks to Preserve History With Playing Cards''], American Forces Press Service, June 22, 2007 *[http://today.colostate.edu/index.asp?url=display_story&story_id=1003196 ''Archaeological playing cards for troops developed by CSU's CEMML''], [[Colorado State University]] website, October 30, 2007 ==External links== *The archaeology awareness playing cards can be viewed at http://cchag.org/index.php/what-we-do/in-theater-training-aids/cpp-playing-cards/ *The archaeology awareness playing cards can be viewed in pdf format at http://www.acq.osd.mil/ie/images/08-09-07cardsuitspuzzlessm.pdf {{DEFAULTSORT:Archaeology Awareness Playing Cards}} [[Category:Iraq War]] [[Category:Ephemera]] [[Category:Playing cards]] [[Category:United States Department of Defense]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Text societies to [[:Category:Text publication societies]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
The '''Bannatyne Club''', named in honour of [[George Bannatyne]] and his famous anthology of Scots literature the [[Bannatyne Manuscript]], was a [[text publication society]] founded by [[Walter Scott|Sir Walter Scott]] to print rare works of [[Scotland|Scottish]] interest, whether in history, poetry, or general literature. It printed 116 volumes in all. It was dissolved in 1861.
==Members== {{Expand list|date=January 2012}}
===Founder members of February 7, 1823===
* [[Sir Walter Scott]] * [[Thomas Thomson (advocate)|Thomas Thomson]] * [[Thomas Kinnear]] * [[David Laing (antiquary)|David Laing]] * [[William Adam of Blair Adam]] * [[Sir William Arbuthnot, 1st Baronet]] * [[James Ballantyne]] * [[William Bannatyne, Lord Bannatyne]] * Robert Bell * [[John Clerk, Lord Eldin]] * [[Henry Cockburn, Lord Cockburn]] * [[Archibald Constable]] * David Constable * Robert Dundas of Arniston * Robert Graham of Balgowan * [[Henry Jardine]] of Harwood * [[John Lee (university principal)|Rev. John Lee]] * [[James Maidment]] * [[Gilbert Laing Meason]] * [[John Murray, Lord Murray]] * [[Robert Pitcairn (antiquary)|Robert Pitcairn]] * [[Samuel Shepherd|Sir Samuel Shepherd]] * [[James Skene of Rubislaw]] * George Smythe * [[Patrick Fraser Tytler]] (1823)
===Further Members admitted November 25, 1823===
* [[Gilbert Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound, 2nd Earl of Minto]] * [[George Chalmers (antiquarian)|George Chalmers]] * William Blair of Avonton * James T. Gibson-Craig * [[Andrew Skene]] * [[Thomas Maitland, Lord Dundrennan]]
===Later members=== {{Expand list|date=January 2012}}
* [[George Hamilton-Gordon, 4th Earl of Aberdeen]] (1827) * [[Alexander Hamilton, 10th Duke of Hamilton]] (1828) * [[Earl of Ashburnham]] * [[John Russell, 6th Duke of Bedford]] * [[Henry Vassall-Fox, 3rd Baron Holland]] * [[Cosmo Innes]] * [[Robert Pitcairn]]
===February 1859=== * [[George Hamilton-Gordon, 4th Earl of Aberdeen|The Earl of Aberdeen]] * [[William Patrick Adam|William Patrick Adam, Esq]] * [[Bertram Ashburnham, 4th Earl of Ashburnham|The Earl of Ashburnham]] * Lord Belhaven and Hamilton * William Blair * Beriah Botfield, Esq., MP * Marquess of Breadalban * Sir Thomas MakDougall Brisbane * George Brodie, Esq * Charles Dashwood Bruce, Esq * Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry * Dean Richard Butler * Sir Hugh Hume Campbell * James Campbell, Esq * Thomas Carnegy, Esq * Earl of Cawdor * Patrick Chalmers, Esq * Right Hon. Sir George Clerk * David Constable, Esq * Thomas Constable, Esq * Andrew Coventry, Esq * David Cowan, Esq * James T. Gibson Craig, Esq (Treasurer) * Sir William Gibson Craig * Marquess of Dalhousie * George Home Drummond, Esq * Henry Drummond, Esq, MP * Right Hon. Sir David Dundas * George Dundas, Esq. * William Pitt Dundas, Esq * Earl of Ellesmere * Joseph Walter King Eyton, Esq * Lieut.-Col. Robert Ferguson, MP * Count Mercer De Flahault * Earl of Gosford * William Gott, Esq * Robert Graham, Esq * Earl of Haddington * [[William Hamilton, 11th Duke of Hamilton|Duke of Hamilton and Brandon]] * Sir Thomas Buchan Hepburn * James Maitland Hog, Esq * Right Hon. John Hope, Lord Justice-Clerk * Cosmo Innes, Esq * Daved Iriving, LL.D * Hon. James Ivory, Lord Ivory * David Laing, Esq (Secretary) * John Bailey Langhorne, Esq * The Earl of Lauderdale * Very Rev. Principal John Lee, DD * Lord Lindsay * James Loch, Esq * The Marquess of Lothian * Lord Lovat * James MacKenzie, Esq * John Whiteford MacKenzie, Esq * Keith Stewart MacKenzie, Esq * William Forbes MacKenzie, Esq * James Maidment, Esq * Sir William Maxwell, Bart * The Hon. William Leslie Melville * The Earl of Minto * James Moncreiff, Esq., MP * The Earl of Morton * James Patrick Muirhead, Esq * Hon. Sir John A. Murray, Lord Murray * Robert Nasmyth, Esq * Hon. Charles Neaves * Lord Neaves * The Earl of Northesk * Lord Panmure * Alexander Pringle, Esq * John Richardson, Esq * Duke of Roxburghe * Reverend Hew Scott * James R. Hope Scott, Esq * Earl of Selkirk * James Young Simpson, MD * Alexander Sinclair, Esq * James Skene, Esq * William Smythe, Esq * John Spottiswoode, Esq * Edward Stanley, Esq * Reverend William Stevenson, DD * Hon. Charles Francis Stuart * Duke of Sutherland * Archibald Campbell Swinton, Esq * Alexander Thomson, Esq * Sir Walter Calverley Trevelyan * William B. D. D. Turnbull, Esq. * Adam Urquart, Esq * Alexander Maconochie Welwood, Esq.
<ref>https://archive.org/details/catalogueofgr10600univuoft</ref>
==Publications== {{Expand list|date=January 2012}}Full texts of the complete Bannatyne Club publications are available online through the National Library of Scotland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://digital.nls.uk/84240852|title=Bannatyne Club|last=|first=|date=|website=National Library of Scotland|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-21}}</ref> * Memoirs touching the Revolution in Scotland, originally published 1714, [[Colin Lindsay, 3rd Earl of Balcarres]] (1841) * The Bannatyne Miscellany; Containing Original Papers and Tracts Chiefly Relating to the History and Literature of Scotland [Published in Edinburgh] (1827) * Melville of Halhill, Sir James, Memoirs of His Own Life, ed. T. Thomson (1827) * Laing, D. ed., Original Letters relating to the Ecclesiastical Affairs of Scotland, 2 vols (Published in Edinburgh, 1851) * Siege of the Castle of Edinburgh MDCLXXXIX, presented to the Bannatyne Club by Robert Bell (1828) * The Æneid of Virgil Translated into Scottish Verse by Gavin Douglas, Bishop of Dunkeld, 2 vols. (1839)
==References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == *[https://archive.org/stream/listsmembersand01scotgoog#page/n10/mode/2up ''The Bannatyne Club- Lists of members and the rules with a catalogue of the books. ''Edinburgh 1867.] *[http://digital.nls.uk/84240852 Bannatyne Club Publications - National Library of Scotland] {{Nuttall}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Charles Lawrence Hutchinson | image = Painting (photograph copy) of Charles L. Hutchinson, (1890-1924), by the artist Gari Melchers (1860-1932), apf1-05179.png | caption = Photographic image of a painting of Hutchinson by the artist [[Gari Melchers]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1854|3|7|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Lynn, Massachusetts]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1924|10 |7 |1854|3|7|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Chicago]], Illinois | occupation = {{hlist|Banker|President of the [[Chicago Board of Trade]]<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=NO CONTEST HERE – A Rousing Majority Given Charles L. Hutchinson for President of the Board - The Largest Vote Ever Cast in the History of the Organization - Ballots Dropped Quietly and Steadily – What May Be Expected of the Winner – ALL RECORDS BEATEN |journal=The Daily Inter-Ocean |volume=XVI |issue=289 |date=January 10, 1888 |page=8}}</ref>|Philanthropist}} | spouse = Frances (née Kinsley) Hutchinson (1857–1936) | parents = Sarah (née Ingalls) and {{nobr|Benjamin P. Hutchinson}} }} '''Charles Lawrence Hutchinson''' (March 7, 1854 – October 7, 1924) was a prominent Chicago business leader and philanthropist who is best remembered today as the founding and long-time president of the [[Art Institute of Chicago]].
== Background == [[File:Charles L. Hutchinson house 2709 S. Prairie.jpg|330px|thumb|left|Charles and Frances Hutchinson were residents of Chicago's elite [[Prairie Avenue]], living for over three decades in this house at 2709. The original house was designed in 1881 by George O. Garnsey and built in the [[Queen Anne style architecture|Queen Anne]] style, and remodeled as shown here in 1888 to [[French Gothic architecture|French Gothic]] tastes by Francis M. Whitehouse. After the neighborhood became less fashionable in the early years of the 20th century, the Hutchinsons moved to a cooperative apartment on E. Walton Place and their former home became a [[boarding house]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Hilliard |first=Celia |title=The Prime Mover - Charles L. Hutchinson and the Making of The Art Institute of Chicago|year=2010 |publisher=The Art Institute of Chicago |location=Chicago |issn=0069-3235 |pages=51–52}}</ref> It has since been demolished.]]Hutchinson was born in Lynn, Massachusetts in 1854 to Benjamin P. Hutchinson (1828-1899)<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=HUTCHINSON IS DEAD – Famous Board of Trade Operator Dies at Lake Geneva – FAILURE OF HEART – End is Hastened by an Attack of the Grip – Noted as one of the most Famous Men in the Financial History of the City |journal=The Daily Inter-Ocean |volume=XXVII |issue=358 |date=March 17, 1899 |page=3}}</ref> and Sarah (née Ingalls) Hutchinson (1833-1909), and relocated with his family to [[Chicago]] in 1856 after a brief stay in Milwaukee. In Chicago Benjamin Hutchinson founded Chicago Packing & Provision Co., which for many years was the leading meat processor in the United States.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Encyclopedia of Chicago |editor1-last=Grossman |editor1-first=James R. |editor2-last=Durkin Keating |editor2-first=Ann |editor3-last=Reiff |editor3-first=Janice L. |year=2004 |publisher=The University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago |isbn=0-226-31015-9 |page=971 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> In 1863 he became one of the first directors of the [[First Chicago Bank|First National Bank of Chicago]]<ref>{{cite book |title=The First National Bank of Chicago - Charter Number Eight - A brief history of its progress from the day it opened for business, July 1, 1863, to the same date half a century later, etc. |last=Sperber |first=Jonathan |authorlink= |year=2005 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge |isbn=0-521-83907-6 |page= |pages=68–69 et al |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> and in 1881 founded the Corn Exchange Bank<ref>{{cite book |title=The History of Chicago from the Earliest Period to the Present Time in Three Volumes - Volume III - From the Great Fire of 1871 to 1885 |editor-last=Andreas |editor-first=Alfred T. |authorlink= |year=1886 |publisher=The A.T. Andreas Company |location=Chicago |isbn= |page=441 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> (with subsequent mergers and acquisitions now [[Bank of America]])<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=THE GREAT SPECULATOR FAILS – Mr. Hutchinson Leaves Chicago and his Trades Closed Out |journal=The New York Times |volume=XL |issue=12,379 |date=April 30, 1891 |page=1}}</ref> and as a member of the [[Chicago Board of Trade]] was known as one of the city’s wealthiest and most colorful speculators.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Special Dispatch for the Chronicle |first= |title=OLD HUTCH FAILS – He Suddenly Leaves for Florida – All His Margin Accounts Closed Out – A Flurry in Chicago but no Failures – The Veteran Speculator Insane |journal=The San Francisco Chronicle |volume=LII |issue=105 |date=April 30, 1891 |page=1}}</ref> Charles graduated from the Chicago public schools in 1872 and entered the business world as a clerk in his father's office, becoming a junior partner with his father in 1875 in the firm B.P. Hutchinson and Son., commission merchants.<ref>{{cite book |title=Biographical Dictionary of American Business Leaders, H-M |last=Ingham |first=John N. |authorlink= |year=1983 |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=Westport, Connecticut; London, England |isbn=0-313-23908-8 |page= 650|pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> Although he never attended college, he was a founding trustee<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO – Men Who Will Act as Directors of the New University Here - Representative Chicagoans Who Are Among Those on the Board – It Is Said that Mr. E. Nelson Blake Will Be the President – THEY WILL MEET TO-DAY |journal=The Daily Inter-Ocean |volume= |issue= |date=July 9, 1890 |page=5}}</ref> and the first treasurer of the University of Chicago,<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=GIVES THEM A MILLION – Rockefeller’s Additional Present to the University of Chicago – THE PRESENTATION LETTER – Directions of the Donor as to Its Expenditure – PROF. HARPER MADE PRESIDENT – He Is Given Six Months in Which to Accept the Honor – DETAILS OF ORGANIZATION COMPLETED |journal=The Chicago Daily Tribune |volume=L |issue=CCLXII |date=September 19, 1890 |page=1}}</ref> positions he held until his death. He married Frances Angeline Kinsley, daughter of [[Herbert Milton Kinsley]], on May 26, 1881.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Accessions – For the Museum |journal=Bulletin of the Chicago Historical Society |issue= |date=May 1925 |page=18}}</ref> Herbert Kinsley had, in the last decades of the 19th Century, become one of Chicago’s premier caterers and restaurateurs after having made his reputation during his peripatetic career in part by hosting a ball for the [[Prince of Wales]] at the Anglo-American Hotel in [[Hamilton, Ontario]] [[Canada]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Cropsey |first=Eugene H. |title=Crosby's Opera House: Symbol of Chicago's Cultural Awakening |year=1999 |publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press |location=Madison |isbn=0-8386-3822-8 |pages=376–377}}</ref>
Because of his contributions to the world of philanthropy, art and education Hutchinson was twice awarded honorary degrees by what is today [[Tufts University]], the first one a being a [[Master of Arts]] in 1901,<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Degree conferred upon Conger |journal=The Daily Inter-Ocean |volume= |issue= |date=June 20, 1901 |page=9}}</ref> and the second one an [[Doctor of Laws|LL.D]] in 1920.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=HOOVER ALUMNUS OF TUFTS – Awarded Degree at Commencement Exercises |journal=Boston Post |volume= |issue= |date=June 22, 1920 |page=5}}</ref> Hutchinson was also the recipient of an honorary Master of Arts degree by [[Harvard University]] in 1915.<ref>{{cite journal |last=International News Service |first= |title=Harvard Makes M.T. Herrick LL.D |journal=New Castle News |volume= |issue= |date=June 24, 1915 |page=2}}</ref> For his service as [[Consul (representative)|consul general]] for Greece in Chicago<ref>{{cite book |last=Henschen |first=Henry N. |title=A History of the State Bank of Chicago from 1879 To 1904 |year=1905 |publisher=Lakeside Press |location=Chicago |isbn= |pages=22–23, 41}}</ref> during the [[World's Columbian Exposition]],<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=BELOIT COLLEGE IN LUCK – Secures the Greek Exhibit at The Fair of Casts from the Antique |journal=The Daily Inter-Ocean |volume=XXII |issue=249 |date=November 30, 1893 |page=7}}</ref> Hutchinson was awarded the Badge of the [[Order of the Redeemer]] by [[George I of Greece|King George I]] of Greece in 1908.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Chicago Men and Women Honored by Kings, Queens and Emperors |journal=The Chicago Sunday Tribune |issue= |date=March 15, 1908 |page=8}}</ref> He was granted a [[knight]]hood by King [[Albert I of Belgium]] in 1919 for his work with the Belgian Relief Committee during [[World War I]],<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=U.S. Food Officials Decorated by Belgium|journal=The Indianapolis Star |issue= |date=May 1919 |page=11}}</ref> and was a supporter of the founding of the [[League of Nations]] at the war's end.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=First Step for World League by Chicagoans - President Lowell of Harvard inspires 500 to Plan to Impose Peace by Sword |journal=The Chicago Sunday Tribune |issue= |date=January 7, 1917 |page=4}}</ref>
Hutchinson served as Chairman, Committee of Fine Arts for the World’s Columbian Exposition of 1893.<ref>{{cite book |last=Cropsey |first=Eugene H. |title=Crosby's Opera House: Symbol of Chicago's Cultural Awakening |year=1999 |publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press |location=Madison |isbn=0-8386-3822-8 |pages=376–377}}</ref>
== The Art Institute of Chicago == "Established in 1879 from the remnants of a foundering art academy, the Art Institute of Chicago grew into a sturdy organization largely through the efforts of ... Hutchinson, who served as its president from 1882 to 1924."<ref>{{cite book |last=Hilliard |first=Celia |title=The Prime Mover - Charles L. Hutchinson and the Making of The Art Institute of Chicago|year=2010 |publisher=The Art Institute of Chicago |location=Chicago |issn=0069-3235 |pages=back cover}}</ref> Although Hutchinson’s personal wealth was generated thru banking, grain speculation and meatpacking enterprises that his father had established after coming to Chicago in 1856, Charles L. Hutchinson’s “greatest enthusiasm was for art and the establishment and growth of the Art Institute”.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mms.newberry.org/xml/xml_files/Hutchinson.xml |title=INVENTORY OF THE CHARLES L. HUTCHINSON PAPERS, 1868-1934 |publisher=The Newberry Library |accessdate=2015-09-17}}</ref> Founded on May 24, 1879<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=The Art Institute – The Western Art Movement and its Splendid Achievements in Chicago – The New Home of the Fine Arts – The Ward Collection – The Century, Harper’s - The Formal Opening of the New Museum – The Loan Collection – A Noble Triumph |journal=The (Chicago) Inter Ocean |volume=XVI |issue=239 |date=November 20, 1887 |page=9}}</ref> as The Chicago Academy of Fine Arts; The Art Institute assumed its present name in 1882.<ref>{{cite book |last=Zukowsky |first=John |title=Chicago Architecture – 1872-1922 – Birth of a Metropolis |year=1987 |publisher=Prestel |location=Munich, London, New York |isbn=3-7913-2344-X |pages=8}}</ref> Hutchinson was a founding trustee of the Chicago Academy of Fine Arts, and recognizing his energy and vision, was named by the board of trustees as its first president three years later when it was renamed the Art Institute of Chicago. As one of many accolades conferred on Hutchinson by the Art Institute, the trustees passed a resolution On October 22, 1907 dedicating Gallery 32 as the Charles Lawrence Hutchinson Gallery of Old Masters to commemorate Hutchinson’s twenty-fifth anniversary as president of the institution.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=The Charles Lawrence Hutchinson Gallery of Old Masters |journal=Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago |volume=I |issue=1 |date=October 1907 |page=1}}</ref> After he died in 1924, his obituary notice in ''The Bulletin of the Art Institute'' noted that “His entire life was devoted to public service, but his service to the Art Institute was so intimate, his devotion so complete that it is not possible to measure it. He ''was'' The Art Institute, and it will stand as his most permanent monument”.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Charles Lawrence Hutchinson – 1854-1924 |journal=Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago |volume=XVIII |issue=9 |date=December 1924 |page=110}}</ref>
===The Art Institute on the move=== [[File:Pike's Building 170 State Street c.1900.jpg|thumb|left|350px|State Street looking north at Monroe c. 1900. '''Pike's Building''' at 170 (now 106 S.) State Street, where the Art Institute first opened its doors as The Academy of Fine Arts, is shown to the far left, with the second [[Palmer House]] (1873) directly across the street on the far right.]][[File:Battery D Armory Old Monroe Street.jpg|thumb|left|350px|'''Battery D Armory''' stood on the east side of Michigan Avenue at Monroe Street. The building was used for various purposes, and "It appears that it occasionally required some pretty quick work to put the building into suitable condition for the morning art classes, after [the building] had been used the night before for a boxing match or a ball."<ref>{{cite book|last=Mack|first=Edwin F.|title=Old Monroe Street : notes on the Monroe Street of early Chicago days|year=1914|publisher=Central Trust Company of Illinois|location=Chicago|isbn=|pages=74}}</ref> It was demolished in 1896.]][[File:Chicago Club crop.jpg|thumb|right|350px|The [[John Wellborn Root]]-designed building at the southwest corner of '''Michigan and Van Buren''', which opened in 1887. The building was sold to the [[Chicago Club]] in 1891 for $425,000,<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first=|title= Why Chicago Smiles - The Treasures of the Earth Pouring into Her Lap - She is Repeating the Progress of Venice, Culture Following Wealth - She "Gets There" with Equal Celerity as a Sea Port and as an Art Center |journal=The York (PA) Daily|volume=LXVII | issue = 6726|date=June 17, 1892|pages=3}}</ref> and collapsed during an extensive renovation of the property by the club in 1929.]][[File:ARTIC Catalogue of the First Annual Exhibition of Original Designs for Decorations, etc. 1902.jpg|thumb|right|350px|1902 exterior view of what is now the '''Allerton Building''' of the Art Institute of Chicago. Although the building was originally designed as a closed rectangle, it was initially constructed with a U-shaped footprint for lack of funds, with the area between the wings of the U in the back filled in 1895 with a temporary structure designed to house the classrooms of the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago|School of the Art Institute]]. Alexander N. Fullerton Memorial Hall, with its [[Louis Comfort Tiffany|Tiffany]] stained glass dome, was completed in 1898, and in 1901 the Ryerson Library was finished,<ref>{{cite book|last=Hogan|first=Erin|title=The Art Institute of Chicago from 1879 to the Modern Wing|year=2009|publisher=Scale Art Publishers, Inc.|location=New York|isbn=1857595807|pages=74}}</ref> funded with a $50,000 donation ($1.4 million in 2015) provided by Hutchinson's friend Martin Ryerson.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hogan|first=Erin|title=Twenty-first Annual Report of the Trustees for the Year Ending June 1, 1900 with Reports of the Treasurer, Director and Librarian, Catalogue of Members, List of Gifts, etc.; Together with the By-laws |year=1900|publisher=The Art Institute of Chicago|location=Chicago|isbn=|pages=9, 19}}</ref>]]Charles L. Hutchinson saw the Art Institute thru every move and building program from the time of its founding until the time of his death in 1924. The institution’s first headquarters were located in Pike's Building at 170 State St.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=(classified advertisement ) Educational Directory – Art School|journal=The (Chicago) Inter Ocean|volume= IX| issue = 1 12|date= July 31, 1880 |page=1}}</ref> in the rooms of the recently defunct Chicago Academy of Design. They remained there until May 1 of 1882, when Hutchinson recognized that the growth of the organization required a larger facility that featured more artist-friendly accommodation. At that time the group relocated to rooms on the second floor of the D Battery Armory on Michigan Avenue<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Art in Chicago -Studio and Gallery Notes|journal=The Chicago Daily Tribune|volume= XLI| issue = |date= May 7, 1882|page=20}}</ref> (located just north of where today the Allerton Building of the Art Institute is located). The drive for what was intended to be a permanent facility also began that year when Hutchinson acquired a lot at the southwest corner of Michigan Avenue and VanBuren Street that had built on it a two-story commercial building that was leased in part to a medical college, for which he advanced the Art Institute the purchase price of $45,000.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Real Estate – A Fair Activity in Building Not Withstanding High Prices – Details of Mr. Pullman’s Plan for a New Residence Suburb – It Will Have a Certainty of Rapid and Elegant Transit – Improvements at Woodlawn, Lake View, South Chicago and Elsewhere |journal=The Chicago Daily Tribune |volume=I |issue=1 |date=July 23, 1882 |page=9}}</ref> The Art Institute moved its offices into the vacant part of the building,<ref>{{cite book |title=The History of Chicago from the Earliest Period to the Present Time in Three Volumes - Volume III - From the Great Fire of 1871 to 1885 |editor-last=Andreas |editor-first=Alfred T. |authorlink= |year=1886 |publisher=The A.T. Andreas Company |location=Chicago |isbn= |page=421 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> and subsequent to the purchase a three story addition of pressed brick was built on the back portion of the lot. Classes moved from the armory into this new space on January 8, 1883 <ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Gossip of the Home Studios and Galleries|journal=The Chicago Daily Tribune|volume= | issue = |date= January 7, 1883|page=10}}</ref> and these accommodations remained the extent of the Art Institute's real estate holdings until 1885, when the lot to the immediate south was acquired for expansion. Because of the organization's continued rapid growth the medical college building was demolished in 1885 and a new building by [[John Wellborn Root]] was built around the 1882 structure to provide more classrooms, galleries and museum space, with a portion of the building set aside for artistically-oriented tenants and organizations whose rent was intended to help pay for the new building and its operations.<ref>{{cite book |last=Hilliard |first=Celia |author2= |year=2010 |title=The Prime Mover: Charles L. Hutchinson and the Making of the Art Institute of Chicago |series=Museum Studies (36.1) |publisher=The Art Institute of Chicago |location=New York |isbn=0-86559-238-1 |pages=23–24}}</ref> Contemporary news reports credited the efforts of Hutchinson as being the drive behind the construction of the new building and “the one man to whom the Art Institute owes its splendid status”.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=The Art Institute – The Western Art Movement and its Splendid Achievements in Chicago – The New Home of the Fine Arts – The Ward Collection – The Century, Harper’s - The Formal Opening of the New Museum – The Loan Collection – A Noble Triumph |journal=The (Chicago) Inter Ocean |volume=XVI |issue=239 |date=November 20, 1887 |page=9}}</ref> Under Hutchinson's watch, plans for expansion of the museum's collection and the building program continued unabated. He used his influence as an organizer of the World's Columbian Exposition to acquire property for a new building for the Art Institute on the east side of Michigan Avenue in Lake Park (today [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]]) on landfill that had been created with debris from the [[Great Chicago Fire]]. On this property was then located a structure that was initially designed and built as a conference center for the fair, but that afterwards became the new home of the Art Institute. It was intended that proceeds from the sale of the VanBuren Street building and $200,000 from the directors of the fair would provide the Art Institute with "a permanent home for art works which will eclipse everything in the nature of fine structures Chicago has known hitherto".<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Art Notes|journal=The New York Times |volume= |issue= |date=November 20, 1891|page=10}}</ref> This new structure (now the Allerton Building) replaced the Exposition Building (built in 1873) that was standing on the site, and was designed by [[Shepley, Rutan and Coolidge]], the later of whom was a friend of Hutchinson's having been the architect of [[Hutchinson Commons|Hutchinson Hall]] at the University of Chicago (1890). The Art Institute moved into the new structure in November 1893 after the fair closed, and Hutchinson spent the next several years leading the effort to reconfigure the interior of the new building. The work entailed the building of the Grand Staircase and the creation of space for the school, libraries, galleries, and the filling of that space with world-class art acquired locally or (more frequently) thru buying expeditions to [[Europe]] and [[Asia]]. <br /> As the Art Institute was not able to provide Hutchinson with the generous purse that would be required for that purpose in those early days, this feat was effected thru Hutchinson's personal connections to Chicago's wealthiest families. An early coup in this regard for Hutchinson and [[Martin A. Ryerson]], a fellow trustee and his frequent companion in these forays, was the 1889 purchase, "at great sacrifice" to the seller, of thirteen seventeenth century [[Dutch Golden Age painting|Dutch]] paintings that were purchased for $200,000, the money for which was advanced by [[Marshall Field]], [[Philip Danforth Armour|Philip Armour]] and others.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=FAMOUS PICTURES FOR CHICAGO - C.L. Hutchinson Tells How He Secured Gems from the Demidoff Collection|journal=The (Chicago) Daily Tribune|volume= |issue= |date=July 3, 1890|page=3}}</ref> ''The New York Press'' sniffed at this effort in what was perceived as an example of Chicago’s cultural barbarism, considering the city’s position as hog butcher to the world and its philistine reputation as a resolute accumulator of wealth for its own sake by whatever means: “He (Hutchinson) probably paid $1,000 a front foot for them, and we assume the citizens of Chicago will give him a triumphal procession when they arrive, carrying them and him in huge floats, drawn by teams of milk-white Berkshire hogs that have been newly washed with a ten inch hose jet of water until their pink flesh shows under the clean bristles.”<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Chicago Gets Some Corkers|journal=The New York Press|volume= |issue= |date=July 9, 1890|page=4}}</ref> Hutchinson's connections would serve the Art Institute well over the next few decades. Among the notable additions to the museum's collection acquired through them included bequests by [[Bertha Honoré Palmer|Bertha Palmer]], Martin L. Ryerson and Clarence Buckingham, whose gifts would add resources which respectively formed the basis of the museum's notable [[Impressionism|Impressionist]] collection and augmented other collections with more than two hundred additional Old Master, Impressionist, and Post-Impressionist paintings and 1,400 Japanese woodblock prints.<ref>{{cite book |last=Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies - Vol. 19 No.1 |first= |title=From the Archives: Photographs of the Art Institute of Chicago, 1893-1933|year=1993 |publisher=The Art Institute of Chicago |location=Chicago |isbn=|pages=12, 18}}</ref><br /> In 1912 a bridge was built to span the by-then suppressed tracks of the Illinois Central Railroad that ran immediately behind the 1893 building, and in 1916 a two-story structure was built on top of it, funded with a $50,000 donation made by railroad inventor William H. Miner. This structure was named Gunsaulus Hall to honor [[Frank W. Gunsaulus]], museum trustee and the first president of the [[Illinois Institute of Technology|Armour Institute]], and housed the museum's industrial arts and related media collection <ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Inventor Gives Institute $50,000 for Industrial Art - W. H. Miner Enables Construction of Hall to House Valuable Collection|journal=The Chicago Daily Tribune |volume= |issue= |date=November 6, 1915 |page=1}}</ref> (the Alsdorf Galleries today occupy the first floor of that space). By 1920 there were talks in earnest regarding the addition of McKlintock Court and the Hutchinson Wing which surrounds it and the [[Goodman Theater]]/[[The Theatre School at DePaul University|Goodman School of Drama]], which was a gift of the family of the playwright Kenneth S. Goodman, who died in 1918. Ground for the building of the latter pair (by [[Howard Van Doren Shaw]]) was broken in 1923 <ref>{{cite journal |last=|first= |title= Ground Broken for Civic Theater in Grant Park|journal=The Chicago Daily Tribune | volume= | issue = |date= June 28, 1923|page=19}}</ref> and the theater opened to the public in 1925.<ref>{{cite journal |last=[[Richard Christiansen (critic)|Christiansen]] |first= Richard |title= Commentary - A Good Move - Goodman's relocation would benefit theater, city|journal=The Chicago Tribune | volume= | issue = |date= June 26, 1988|page=M14-15}}</ref>
== Affiliations == Hutchinson believed that a man’s secret of success lie not only in “intense industry”, but also in “his recreations [that] make or break him as surely as do his business habits”.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title= How to Succeed |journal=Chicago Livestock World= | volume= XIII| issue = 82 |date= March 18, 1912|page=8}}</ref> Over the course of his lifetime, Hutchinson was president, board member, trustee and/or supporter of perhaps as many as seventy commercial, civic and philanthropic institutions. Among those were included:
===Business/Commercial===
* [[Chicago Board of Trade]], president<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Hutchinson Chosen |journal=The Decatur Herald |volume=L |issue= |date=January 11, 1888 |page=1}}</ref> * Chicago City Railway Co., director<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=ANNUAL ELECTIONS – Chicago City Railway Company |journal=The Daily Inter-Ocean |volume=IX |issue=252 |date=January 11, 1881 |page=8}}</ref> * [[Commercial Club of Chicago]], President, Vice-President, Treasurer<ref>{{cite book |last=Farwell |first=John V., president |title=The Commercial Club of Chicago Yearbook, 1908|year=1908 |publisher=The Executive Committee |location=Chicago |isbn=1333060742 |pages=23}}</ref> * Corn Exchange Bank, president<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=advertisement – Corn Exchange Bank |journal=The Chicago Daily Tribune |volume=L |issue= |date=January 15, 1890 |page=10}}</ref> * [[Northern Trust|Northern Trust Bank]], director<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=advertisement –The Northern Trust Company Bank |journal=The Economist |volume= |issue= |date=January 25, 1902 |page=125}}</ref> * State Bank of Chicago (after mergers [[Chase (bank)|Chase Bank]]), founding director,<ref>{{cite book |last=Henschen |first=Henry N. |title=A History of the State Bank of Chicago from 1879 To 1904 |year=1905 |publisher=Lakeside Press |location=Chicago |isbn=1-164-11964-8 |pages=22–23, 41}}</ref> * Western Stone Company, director<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=The Western Stone Company |journal=Stone – An Illustrated Magazine |volume=X |issue=3 |date=February 1895 |page=233}}</ref>
===Civic===
* [[Auditorium Building, Chicago|Chicago Auditorium Association]], director, secretary<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Chicago Auditorium Association |journal=The Economist Investor’s Manual |volume= | issue = |date=May 1902 |page=68}}</ref> * Chicago Opera Association, treasurer<ref>{{cite book |last= Langland|first=James |title=The Chicago Daily News Almanac and Year-Book for 1921|year=1920|publisher=The Chicago Daily News Company|location=Chicago |isbn= |pages=873}}</ref> * [[Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago|Chicago Sanitary District]], treasurer.<ref>{{cite book |title= Proceedings of the Board of Trustees of the Sanitary District of Chicago|last= Hutchinson |first= Charles L. (treasurer) |authorlink= |first2= Chas. A. (assistant treasurer) |last2=Foot |year= 1908|publisher= Fred Klein Co.|location= Chicago|isbn= |page= 232|pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> * [[Chicago Symphony Orchestra]], trustee<ref>{{cite journal |last= French|first= Florence |title=THE EVOLUTION OF AN ORCHESTRA – Chicago’s Great Symphony Result of New York’s Indifference – Theodore Thomas Originator, Frederick Stock the Progressive Follower – Extraordinary Development of Half a Century |journal=The Musical Leader |volume= | issue = |date= June 1, 1922 |page=528}}</ref> * Citizen’s Association of Chicago, treasurer<ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |title=A Local List of Charitable and Philanthropic Organizations BELIEVED BY THE CHICAGO ASSOCIATION OF COMMERCE SUBSCRIPTIONS INVESTIGATING COMMITTEE TO BE WORTHY the SUPPORT OF THOSE WHO DESIRE TO FURTHER THEIR AIMS|year=1915|publisher=The Chicago Association of Commerce & Industry |location=Chicago |isbn= |pages=53}}</ref> * Civic Music Association of Chicago, treasurer<ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |title=A Local List of Charitable and Philanthropic Organizations BELIEVED BY THE CHICAGO ASSOCIATION OF COMMERCE SUBSCRIPTIONS INVESTIGATING COMMITTEE TO BE WORTHY the SUPPORT OF THOSE WHO DESIRE TO FURTHER THEIR AIMS|year=1915|publisher=The Chicago Association of Commerce & Industry |location=Chicago |isbn= |pages=56}}</ref> * Fine Arts Committee, The [[World’s Columbian Exposition]], chairman and director<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Fair Plan Reaffirmed – The Electrical Layout of the Exposition Will Be Adhered to Exactly – Horticultural Chief Maxwell - Chief Putnam’s Curios – Miss Couzins – The Ladies – Busienss of the Commissioner’s Board of Control – Other Columbian Pointers|journal=The Daily Inter-Ocean |volume= XX| issue = 38 |date= May 1, 1891 |page=68}}</ref> * Horticultural Society of Chicago (now the Chicago Horticultural Society), director<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=A Garden for June; Peony Show this Week|journal=The Chicago Daily Tribune |volume= | issue = |date= June 8, 1913 |page=5}}</ref> * Illinois Committee on Social Legislation, treasurer<ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |title=A Local List of Charitable and Philanthropic Organizations BELIEVED BY THE CHICAGO ASSOCIATION OF COMMERCE SUBSCRIPTIONS INVESTIGATING COMMITTEE TO BE WORTHY the SUPPORT OF THOSE WHO DESIRE TO FURTHER THEIR AIMS|year=1916|publisher=The Chicago Association of Commerce & Industry |location=Chicago |isbn= |pages=42}}</ref> * Republican Sanitary District Convention, delegate<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Standing by the Ticket – Prominent Men Claimed by the Bolters Assert their Loyalty - It was a Convention of Good Men and it Named Good Men – Facts Which Good Citizens Should Examine Before Election Day|journal=The Daily Inter-Ocean |volume=XVIII | issue = 261 |date= December 10, 1889 |page=6}}</ref> * [[Chicago Park District|South Parks Commission]], commissioner<ref>{{cite book |last= Langland|first=James |title=The Chicago Daily News Almanac and Year-Book for 1921|year=1920|publisher=The Chicago Daily News Company|location=Chicago |isbn= |pages=880}}</ref> * World’s Columbian Exposition, committee of 100<ref>{{cite book |last= Maloney |first= Cathy Jean and the Chicago Botanic Garden |title=Chicago and its Botanic Garden - The Chicago Horticultural Society at 125 |year=2015|publisher=Northwestern University Press|location=Chicago |isbn=0-8101-3095-5 |pages=8}}</ref>
===Educational===
* [[American Federation of Arts]], founding president<ref>{{cite book |last=Millet |first=Frank D., Secretary |title= Proceedings of the Convention at which the American Federation of Arts was Formed - Held at Washington D.C. Crane, 1858-1939: American Businessman, Philanthropist, and a Founder of Russian Studies in America |year=2012 |publisher=Lexington Books |location=Lanham |isbn=0-7391-7745-1 |pages=88}}</ref> * Chicago Manual Training School (University High School), treasurer <ref>{{cite book |last=Johnston|first= Henry Rust|title= The Correlator - Book of the Senior Class: 1905 - University High School|year=1905|publisher=The Senior Class|location=Chicago|isbn= |pages=11}}</ref> * [[Chicago Public Library]], director<ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |title= Twenty-Seventh Annual Report of the Board of Directors of the Chicago Public Library|year=1899|publisher=Geo. K Hazlitt Co. |location=Chicago|isbn= |pages=2}}</ref> * [[Egypt Exploration Society|Egypt Exploration Fund]], vice-president<ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |title=Egypt Exploration Fund – Report of the Nineteenth Ordinary General Meeting (Twenty-third Annual General Meeting) - Subscription List and Balance Sheets – 1904-1905|year=1906|publisher=Kegan Paul, Trench, Trübner & Co. |location=London |isbn= |pages=6}}</ref> * Municipal Art League, treasurer<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=The Municipal Art League of Chicago|journal=Art and Progress |volume=III |issue=12 |date=October 1912 |page=754}}</ref> * National Art Association - [[Smithsonian Institution]], vice-president<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=Catalogue of the First Exhibition of the National Art Association|journal= |volume= |issue= |date=May 18, 1892 |page=2}}</ref> * National University, trustee<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=FAMOUS MEN SELECTED – Board of Trustees of New National University Composed of Many Public Men and Noted Educators |journal=The Illini |volume=XXXI |issue=51 |date=January 29, 1902 |page=1}}</ref> * [[University of Chicago]],trustee, treasurer<ref>{{cite book |last=Boyer |first=John W. |title=The University of Chicago, A History |year=2015 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago |isbn=978-0-226-24265-1 |pages=103}}</ref>
===Religious=== [[File:St. Paul Universalist.jpg|thumb|right|250px|St. Paul Universalist Church, 3005 S. Prairie Avenue, 1887, Burlig and Whitehouse, architects (demolished). The chapel was donated by Hutchinson and Harlow Higinbotham,<ref>{{cite book|last=Tyre|first=William H.|title=Chicago's Historic Prairie Avenue|year=2008|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-7385-5212-5|pages=75}}</ref> who was a partner of [[Marshall Field's|Marshall Field and Company]] and would become the president of the [[World's Columbian Exposition]] and a founder of the [[Field Museum of Natural History|Field Museum]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fieldmuseum.org/founders-advocates |title=Founders and Advocates|publisher=The Field Museum|accessdate=2016-01-24}}</ref>]] * St. Paul's Universalist Church, Sunday school superintendent,<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |title=WELCOME FOR CHARLES L HUTCHINSON – Friends Gather at St. Paul’s Universalist Church to Give Him a Reception |journal=The Chicago Daily Tribune |volume= |issue= |date=May 5, 1894 |page=5}}</ref> president

to Fight Against Evil – CHICAGO WILL BE CENTER – David Starr Jordan Heads American Vigilance Association Which Seeks to Stamp Out "Traffic in the United States |journal=The Urbana Courier-Herald |volume=XV | issue = 75 |date= March 4, 1912 |page=3}}</ref> * Chicago Nursery and Half-Orphan Society, president<ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |title=A Local List of Charitable and Philanthropic
